column1: Direct causes are rare, but include: - Injury to the belly area (abdomen) from a fall, hit to the abdomen, or automobile accident - Sudden loss of uterine volume (can occur with rapid loss of amniotic fluid or after a first twin is delivered) Risk factors include: - Blood clotting disorders (thrombophilias) - Cigarette smoking - Cocaine use - Diabetes - Drinking more than 14 alcoholic drinks per week during pregnancy - High blood pressure during pregnancy (about half of placental abruptions that lead to the baby's death are linked to high blood pressure) - History of placenta abruptio - Increased uterine distention (may occur with multiple pregnancies or very large volume of amniotic fluid) - Large number of past deliveries - Older mother - Premature rupture of membranes (the bag of water breaks before 37 weeks into the pregnancy) - Uterine fibroids Placental abruption, which includes any amount of placental separation before delivery, occurs in about 1 out of 150 deliveries.
